data.text: I would not tour on carbon. Very few if any touring bikes are made out of carbon. High end carbon frames are designed to be rigid in certain areas and flex in others. Carrying a decent amount of kit and gear will cause undue stress on the frame which could cause stress points in the frame where the carbon is designed to give you flex. Admittedly carbon is a very strong material but the design of the carbon layering in the bike frame isn't helpful for extra load carrying capacity on various points on the frame or fork. You could get away with it with a light load and sticking to asphalt roads without very technical riding.

data.text: I am a long term tourer, that has done Ragbrais (450 to 550-mile ride) and a lot of triathlons on my carbon fiber bike, I would never tour on one, first, the stiffness would beat the hell out of you, and most CF frame geometries are not conducive to touring, to tight/short, no mounting lugs, etc. I haven't ridden it on Ragbrai in nearly 20 years either, the lighter weight does not justify the discomfort, IMHO.

data.text: Triathlon bikes are made for minimum resistance, which demands also a very rigid frame. I think CF frames are the relatively most cushioning, at least more the aluminium. I have used since 2000 an early CF frame, then an aluminium, now a CF again, and both are/were more comfortable. Thus your argument is not valid.

data.text: I guess that's your opinion, not mine, and a lot of folks are of the same mindset in this forum. I don't know if they have done 500 miles at a crack on a cf, but I have. My experience has been that my cf beats me up, is uncomfortable but light and fast, my aluminum tourer more comfortable and has a longer wheel base, smooths the bumps pretty good but is still fairly stiff. My new steel tourer, is like riding a dream on fluffy clouds. You are the first person that I've ever heard claim that "CF frames are the relatively most cushioning", but hey maybe I still have more to learn and I can only comment on my own experience.
